I based this off of Fastrack's spool centre feeder, adjusted it to fit a Rep2 better. Lowered it and also the wiringloom stays much closer to the machine with this design, so the metal clips can better hold it in place.
Has nice smooth round guides with clips that allow the filament to be "clipped in" making removing/changing filament spools easy.

Printed with .27 layer height, 10% infill & 2 shells, no support or raft.
Uses 2 standard size zip ties to attach to wiring harness.. Position it at the top of the wiring harness, it will fit just under the metal cutt-out for the wire harness on the Rep2, and carefully tighten the zip ties. Do not over tighten the zip ties, just tighten them enough that the guide can move with a some effort. Clip in your filament - you may have to spread the clip apart slightly. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/6cahhZfEpvt

This is the bastard child between an Ultimaker and a Replicator 3D printer.
I got fed up with belts, alignaments puleys and all that unprecise gear so I made one with ballscrews.
As mentioned above it uses various parts and concepts from those 2 printers. Good, level and strong chassi made of MK profiles and the printer head configuration from the ultimaker.

I have printed some of the STL files and came out great....on an Afinia printer. The bearing holder kept the press fit tolerance and all. I tried printing them on the Ultimaker and while they are usable you need to open some of the holes and smooth out some other parts but usable for sure.
I will post all the hardware that needs to be bought and its size and PN. The ballscrews would need a tough bearing due to the linear forces. As far as the motor there is almost no force required to move the printer head hence the accuracy. The ballscrews are also the most expensive part but if memory servs all the parts still came under $1000 or around that mark.
I will probably be using the Ultimaker controller and with the heated build platform upgrade and PS since I have them already.
And considering the materials the replicator and ultimaker are made of, now I see their markup is way to high for the quality of the product.
All the bashing aside, pls feel free to download the zip file which contains all the working files and assemblies used by SolidWorks and change things as you see fit.
Do let me know if you make any changes so I can incorporate them and pass the on. URGENT!!!!
I found a fatal flaw in the design of some fo the parts and I removed them. Hopefully no harm donw. The ballscrew carraige was imported backwards for some reason which changes EVERYTHING. FRAK! I will fix and reupload all the files once more. My appologies. Ballscrew: Misumi BSSR1405-450
Linear Bearing: Thomson RBL 608ZZ/C3/EMQ/V2
Aluminum Extrusion: MK 25mmX25mm 25Series.
Stepper Motor: SY42STH47-1684B UPDATE! 15/04/13
So I found a fatal flaw in the gear used. I installed the X axis and attached a drill as a motor and went to town. I noticed the far end was jittering. It turns out that the ballscrew has some side movement, which translated in huge movement when reaching the other end.
I will try and troubleshoot to see if there is a fix. But as is BOB is dead in the watter. Sorry everyone. I'll keep you posted.
Cheers.

description.text:
I needed a tray for a bunch of SMD parts.  My first venture into the world of SMD, so I figured any tools that can make it in easier transition would be a good thing...
This is one of those helpful things.
I made it 12 compartments, each 20mm x 20mm.  I also angled the top, thinking that it might help in seeing/grabbing the small parts living in the compartments.
I am printing it as I type this...
I hope it helps you guys/gals.  (and myself as well ;-)

Slice and print. I'd think a non-black/white color would be best, as most SMD's are black, but a few are white.
I went with green. Also included is the OpenSCAD file, in case you'd like to make some changes. I will probably be adding a lid to this thing tonight, once I am done (or have exhausted my patience) with my days soldering and need to put it all away... Solder on, soldier!

description.text: Since Planetside 2 was released, the community has clamored for a means to show off their faction pride while attending weddings and funerals. The wait is over! Print out your very own pair of PS2 cufflinks, emblazoned with the symbol of the Terran Republic, New Conglomerate, or Vanu Sovereignty. These cufflinks can be printed in a single build, no assembly required, without supports. They include a full working hinge on the cufflink back clasp. For a full-color version intended for printing on a ProJet 4500, check out my other thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:567412 Enjoy!

This file is intended for printing standing up, without supports.  The sharp overhang angle does create some defects on the underside of the cufflinks, but this is obscured by your shirt while the cufflinks are being worn.  
I printed these in grey ABS on a Cube printer (2nd gen), and I think they look pretty great!

description.text: This thing evolved from more experimenting in Groboto. All together there are nine autobots in this design. In an earlier version, I had the sphere free to move but captive in the larger bot. However it never stayed in the best position for the overall design. In this final version, I have anchored the sphere in three locations so it is held nicely in place. Just be careful when removing the support structure that you don't trim these posts away.

I used ReplicatorG on a MakerBot Replicator2 with the Replicator 2 slicing defaults and the following settings with white MB PLA: Infill = 10%
Layer Height = 0.200

Feedrate = 40
Travel Feed = 55
Temperature = 220 I used a raft with full support. This version took 8 1/2 hours to print on my MakerBot Replicator2 . It took 72 gms of material to print but the final thing only weights 32 gms. So be patient when trimming the support structure. The "spikes" can be easily broken.

MoPro (Mobius Lens B Action Cam - GoPro Conversion Case) This Case is for the Wide angled Lens (Lens B)
Click on our Account or type blackboxrc into the search to find the MoPro Lens A (Standard Lens) Lens Extension cable is needed. MoPro Skeleton Case can be found at the link below.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:567586 This has been on our list of things to design for a while now and finally its finished. This case will transform your Mobius Action Cam to the MoPro, Sizes match the GoPro Hero 3 Exactly and it also weighs the same. There is a few conversion kits on the market to do this but they have no took into account the weight factor. The whole idea was to make this the same size to fit all of the top GoPro Brushless Gimbals out there which other companies have done but overlooked the weight. The most crucial part of the setup is getting the balance right on the gimbal with the cam on. All of the GoPro gimbals on the market have been designed around the GoPro's size and weight so its balanced perfectly, These company's that have made Mobius Conversion kits have made them to fit these gimbals but the weight is all wrong its too light so its pretty pointless why make a conversion kit for gopro gimbals that just wont work. title: Side Panels for Replicator 2. Easy. Quick. Cheap.

description.text: Want to add slick transparent side panels to your Replicator 2? Just buy some transparent covers, used for making binders and place them between the metal casing and the black side covers.  Good for reducing drafts and dust in your build area.

Buy some transparent Binding Covers :-)
Unscrew the 6 hex bolts at each side of the Rep2 with the hex key provided with your bot.
Lay the transparent cover on the inside of the black Rep2 side panels. Use some transparent tape on the top and bottom to hold the sheets in place (these will be covered and out of sight after mounting).
Mount the sidepanels. finished.
Looks great, costs next to nothing and quick ;-)
Please Note: Nothing to print here, but I had to upload a STL in order to publish this ;-)
So please ignore the STL!

description.text: This is a replacement button for the Sparkfun 35mm Concave Button (https://www.sparkfun.com/products/9339), making it about 5 inches wide. It makes a fun giant button on the top. I debossed a logo onto it for our purposes, but can be used for many purposes.

Just pop out the actual button from the bottom of the Sparkfun 35mm concave button, and squeeze the two pegs on the end of the plastic "button pusher", sliding it out of the casing.   
Put the spring inside the new 3d printed button, and squeeze pegs together as you slide it back into the casing until it snaps in. Replace the actual button in the bottom, and you are good to go!

Now you can attend fancy dinner parties with your faction symbol emblazoned proudly on your wrists, just as you always wanted! These cufflinks include a working hinge, and are intended for printing in full-color plastic on a 3D Systems ProJet 4500. The material is called VisiJet C4 Spectrum. The WRL files here include color. If you want a pair of these cufflinks, I think you could get a set printed and shipped by this 3DHubs service bureau for $35: http://www.3dhubs.com/jacksonville/hubs/forge
Or, if you're in Europe, from these guys for about 20 euros: http://www.3dhubs.com/utrecht/hubs/rapidcenter I also made a monochrome FDM version of these cufflinks, which can be printed in one piece on most FDM printers. That can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:567319 Enjoy!

Intended for printing on a ProJet 4500. Make sure to submit one of the WRL files, as the STL's don't include color data. If you want to try printing these on an FDM printer, make sure to grab the version I designed specifically for that purpose here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:567319 I modified the geometry on that version to reduce the overhangs.

French :  
Bonjour,  
J'ai découvert ce challenge en parcourant le site avec ma fille de 3 ans et demi et elle a tout de suite beaucoup aimé ce petit logo.  
Je lui ai donc fabriqué quelques accessoires.  
Voici donc une barette ghostly.  
L'impression ne pose pas de réel problème.  
Cependant, pour éviter que la partie supérieure ne colle à la partie logo, une petite astuce est de mettre une feuille de papier recouverte de ruban adhésif de peintre entre les deux au cours de l'impression.  
Bonne impression.  
English:  
hello,  
I discovered this challenge by browsing the site with my 3 and half  year old daughter and she immediately loved this little logo.  
So I made her some accessories.  
Here's a ghostly hairclip.  
Printing does not pose a real problem.  
However, to prevent the top from sticking to the party logo, a little trick is to put a piece of paper covered with painter's tape between the two during printing.  
Good impression.  
Changes :   
I made a few small changes to facilitate printing. The hairclip is now separated into two files to be printed one after the other. At the time of printing the party logo, the head of the extruder shifts to print "in the space" which leaves time to put together both parties who show solidarity after printing.

Bonjour,  
J'ai découvert ce challenge en parcourant le site avec ma fille de 3 ans et demi et elle a tout de suite beaucoup aimé ce petit logo.

Voici donc deux porte clés ghostly.

hello,

So I made her some accessories.  
Here are two keychail ghostly.

description.text: Pulley with 42 teeth for GT2 timing belt (6mm wide, 2 mm teeth) with fins that lock into the holes in one particular 80 mm inline skate wheel. This allows use as a drive wheel on a robot. The pulley bore allows a standard 608 skate bearing to fit through it. The fins look overhanging but this .STL file printed out OK without support (PLA on UM2 printer). OpenSCAD file provided so you might modify it to fit other types of wheels and hubs. The pulley itself is taken from droftarts' pulley.

author: stevenwatts

title: P3Steel flexible USB LED frame mount / holder

description.text:
This is a P3Steel frame mount / holder for an inexpensive flexible USB LED light.
I connected it directly to the +5V output of the ATX PSU which I am using to power my P3Steel, so the LED light switches on every time the printer is printing, but of course a separate On/Off switch could be added.
OpenSCAD sources are included so this part can be remixed to taste.

Here shown printed in PLA with 40% infill, there are two small parts to print. The frame mount part uses a single M3 16mm screw which replaces the existing M3 12mm screw in the P3Steel frame. The cover part uses two small nylon ties to firmly attach the USB connector shell.
Assembling: first, fit and screw the frame mount part to the P3Steel frame. Then slide the cover part over the frame mount part, locking the whole assembly in place. Note that the two parts are a tight fit together, and that's on purpose!
ATTENTION! Do not try to power the USB LED light from the Arduino's +5V! The Arduino regulator cannot supply the approximately 300mA required by the USB LED light and would fail almost instantly! I am powering the LED light directly from the +5V line from the ATX PSU which I am using to power the 3D printer itself. If your 3D printer PSU does not have a 5V output, you can use an inexpensive "wall charger" style USB +5V power supply.

A nice exercise in making 3D printable objects for beginners.
Drawing, tracing, extruding

Various objects are redrawn on transparent paper, made into pictures, traced in Inkscape and saved with extension SVG, imported as a sketch in 123D Design, extruded in this program and saved as STL files.  
Both Inkscape and 123D Design are freely available for download on the Internet.
A small doe deer sculpture inspired by a decorative sculpture I saw at Ikea.

Sliced at .2mm thickness with 15% infill.
Assemble printed pieces which only fit together one way.
Glue together or keep as a puzzle.

This is a chain of ball joints that are printed preassembled. It comes as an open chain or as a closed loop.
Print, and enjoy!

The chain is made of ball joints that are printed pre-assembled. You will likely need to apply some force to break them free. The inner spheres are actually slightly deformed so that you can lock the joints in the chosen positions. If a joint does not lock, rotate it around the connector axis - it should become stiffer at some angles. Make sure your plate is properly leveled to avoid the outer and inner spheres to bond on the first layer: this happens if too much plastic is poured due to the plate being too close to the nozzle. The provided 'csg' files can be imported with OpenSCAD and rendered into a stl - both contain 12 ball joints. The result is shown by the image rendered with transparency. This is a parametric model created with my own software. I will release the software soon (still working on it) but I include the script for reference - should be easy to convert to OpenSCAD. Several assemblies are possible:
  • balljoint_chain.csg is an open chain
  • balljoint_cycle.csg is a closed loop
    • I provide stl files for the chain and loop of 8 joints (for some reason OpenSCAD has trouble with the 12 joints version on my computer). I also included gcode of the 12 joints version for my Replicator 1 -- use at your own risk (afaik the code may not work on a different printer). I printed it in ABS, at 0.2mm layer thickness, 120 mm/s travel and 60 mm/sec print speed. These are the settings used in the provided gcode. Have fun!

comments.text: That looks great, what tolerance between inner and outer sphere did you aim for when designing?
comments.author: Sungod3k

comments.text: Thanks - I believe the tolerance is 0.2 mm - but that is not everywhere the same as the inner spheres have protrusions to 'grip' on the outer hull. The file 'balljoint.lua' contains the full code with measures in millimeters.
comments.author: Sungod3k

comments.text: Awesome, glad to see more preassembled things. Just out of curiosity, it seems like you could make this easily in OpenSCAD; what is different about your software?
comments.author: emmett

comments.text: Thanks Emmett! OpenSCAD is great, and you could definitely model this directly with it. My software actually started as a slicer: I got interested in RepRaps, and wanted to understand the process better. Then I realized that you could skip entirely the STL mesh generation by directly slicing the CSG -- this idea is not really novel; it's included in RepRap Host I think ( see http://blog.reprap.org/2011/10/say-goodbye-to-unsightly-stl-triangle.htmlhttp://blog.reprap.org/2011/10... ). My software simply goes a bit further with it, supports meshes as input and uses 'GPU tricks' to make it very fast. For instance, it only takes around 5 minutes to slice this model on my computer (and there is no STL generation - so that's 5 minutes to printing). However, that requires a big NVidia GPU (>= GTX 480). This is definitely not a competitor for OpenSCAD which generates meshes (mine can only slice), this is why there is a button to export the CSG tree and load it in OpenSCAD :).
comments.author: emmett

comments.text: Cool. I played around with writing my own slicer awhile back too; no easy task.
comments.author: sylefeb

comments.text:
Just wanted to point out that the software I developed is now available: http://webloria.loria.fr/~slefebvr/icesl/http://webloria.loria.fr/~slef...
Have fun :)
comments.author: emmett

comments.text: You might want to mention on your site that it is a Windows-only application. While GPU requirements are listed, OS requirements are nowhere to be found and a lot of us RepRappers (and software developers for such) use Linux as our primary OS. As it looks like your app is written in Lua, you may be able to make it multiplatform easily if you use standard OpenGL shaders. It looks promising and I very much look forward to a Linux release =)
comments.author: sylefeb

comments.text: That is a good point - I'll update the description on the website. In fact, a Linux version is on its way, and I was hoping to make it available faster. The app is in C/C++ but uses Lua for modeling language.

description.text: My first File

The Planetary Reduction Drive was a project for a class used to
demonstrate the simplicity of gear reductions in situations such as
vehicles. The part uses the planet gears as the driving gears so you can rotate
the part using your fingers. It's fun and durable, and will have you
mindlessly moving for hours. (Trust me!)

SCALE COMPONENTS DOWN Once printed, bond the connector to the base (using glue) and insert
planet gears into assembly. Then insert sun gear into base assembly
and attach using the nut. Threads may be tight at first, but keep using them and they'll loosen.
Works with up to five planet gears.

title: Ultimaker Bolted Rod End Cap
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
MoonCactus had a great idea with his bolted end caps (thing ID 54075) to minimize possible free play at the ends of the rods of the Ultimaker.
With this remix I revised the nut holder of the end cap in a way I like a bit more.
Of course, it's your choice. If you have even further ideas for improvements don't hesitate to take my design and alter it in any form (at least as long as you share it with the community).

Print in ABS or PLA. I recommend a higher infill rate. Support isn't required. Additional parts you need: 1x M3 nylock nut
1x M3 20 mm bolt (use a thumb/wing screw) Update 2013-03-05: Corrected the orientation of the object in the file, so you don't have to do this manually inside of your slicing software. Update 2013-03-11: Separated into two items, so no more support is required. The thick part takes the nylock nut. The round pocket of the thinner part faces towards the bearing.

For best results printing the antennae in Top1.stl set fan power to 100% and use a minimum layer duration of 5 seconds.

description.text: A cat size toy ball with small balls printed inside.  I wanted one that would print the balls inside and the outer shell in one print, so I made my own.

I printed it using the Makerware medium profile. (After all it's a cat toy, how long do you want to wait?) :)
After the print is done knockout the balls from the holes. I found a springloaded center puch does a good job of that.
Toss it on the floor in front of your cat. I have printed it at different scales just to see how well it worked. Abviously 100% is great. 75% also worked well. 50% so-so. The ball in the bottom hole was fused too tightly to break it free. As I am writing this I realized that if I had rotated the toy to have one of the open holes on the bottom, the 50% would probably have worked also.

My original Exped Sleeping Mat had an awesome feature - its bag could be used to inflate the mat in seconds by attaching it to the mat's air intake and using it as a pump (see below for a more detailed explanation). Unfortunately, that mat died - and its successor replaced the clever and light-weight bag/pump mechanism with a bulky and tediously slow 'built-in pump' system. This thing attempts to resurrect the original mechanism by augmenting any large plastic bag + the top-end of a wide-mouth plastic bottle with a 3D-printed nozzle adapter. The result can inflate my sleeping mat in at most two 'puffs'. My next make will be tailored to my new inflatable kayak, meaning I can leave its pump at home too. Use Customizer to tweak the parameters of your nozzle. Cut/drill a hole in the bottle cap to fit over your nozzle (to lock it into the bottle top-end). Use double-sided tape + regular tape to secure your nozzle+bottle-top-end into the corner of a large plastic bag - use lots of tape, as it needs to be strong and air-tight! It is worth noting that Exped also appears to have resurrected this idea (as a separate product) - take a look at their page if my explanation above doesn't make sense (it's a bit hard to describe).

description.text: This is a 6 start 1/8" ball thread rod.  It uses 1/8" delrin balls.  The nut will work without the balls but the balls make a nut ride smoother and have less wobble. One turn will give 1.125" of travel.

The pitch of the thread is determined by the Number of Starts (Ns) Ball Spacing (Bs) Ball Diameter (D) Ex. 6(Ns) 0.0625(Bs) 0.125(D) = 1.125 Pitch The diameter of the thread can really be anything. The diameter does affect (the thread angle) how easily pushing on the nut will cause the thread to turn. I used 3/4" because that was the inner diameter a pipe I had (giving around 30 degrees).

remixed_from.title: Direct drive extruder for Wilson or Prusa i3 rework

description.text:
This is a remix of the direct drive key by Marty Rice, which he published together with his awesome direct drive extruder (thing #501755).  
It's just a tiny bit stronger and uses a tiny bit more material, otherwise it's almost identical, the main difference is I wrote the code from scratch in OpenSCAD, so it can be remixed at will.  
WARNING: do not try to turn the stepper shaft with this key while the stepper is enabled!  
And also: read the instructions before printing!

This is a very, very tight fit on the 5mm diameter D-shaped shaft of the Chinese steppers I usually use, so I suggest printing scaled up by 3~4% in whatever slicing software you are using.  
This one was printed in PLA with 40% infill.

For a nice linear slide modification, I need to be able to attach a smooth rod in a T formation with a threaded rod. This thing will allow you to thread 5/16" rod in one direction, and slip 5/16 rod into the other axis (the diameter is enlarged for sliding vs threading). The thing is in the shape of a cube, and has the same dimensions as this thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5645

If you have need for a smooth 5/16" rod to be mounted perpendicular to a threaded 5/16" rod then... 1) Print as many of these as you need
2) Thread the threaded rod into the smaller hold
3) Slip the smooth rod into the enlarged hole (does not go all the way through
4) Rejoice!

Puyehue-Cordón Caulle - Constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle (about 1.9 million polygons). This software was created using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I get warping using PLA and it gets bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. I have had 'some' success with big maps. If you have a way to control warping you may also have better luck with big maps.

A limitation of Pepakura is that I can only make the sheet 2000 mm long, a sheet of plywood is about 2400, you will have a 15 inch by 4 feet left over from each sheet. Sorry. Center console is up, can be built on it's own if you do not want to build the whole cockpit.
Center will take 3 and a half sheets of plywood.

Load it up into pepakura, print on either wide format printer or in pieces, cut pieces out on plywood and assemble.  
For buttons, I am planning on using arcade machine buttons and other various switches off amazon and wiring them to the buttons on usb controllers. I've got a few old xbox controllers that I modified to use usb, using XBMC and joytokey I should be able to assign any keyboard or mouse input to what ever button I want.  
If you make it, I want pictures.

As soon as I made this linear slide: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5625 I wanted to make a modification. There are a couple of challenges with that first design. First, the very large piece is very hard to print and get totally flat. It wants to warp. Second, the design requires a fixed size separation of the two smooth rods. That's going to be fine for certain loads and directions, and not for others. So, this thing is a piece of a reinterpretation of that design. This one piece simply captures a 608 bearing, and provides a nice stable piece that can be threaded onto a 5/16" threaded rod. This thing, in combination with a couple of these other things: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5678 Would give you what you need to make a linear slide of any size (length and separation) for an endoskeletal bot.

1) Print a couple of these when creating a linear slide.
2) Press fit 608 bearings into the large opening.
3) Thread the thing onto 5/16" rod, with other components
4) Add other components to your design to complete your linear slide
5) Rejoice!

title: Customizable Safe / House / Padlock keys
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Print your own safe, house or padlock key with this easy to use key generator

Warning! - this thing is for printing a PLASTIC key. This key is now optimized for printing at 0.29mm layers, and is only 7 layers thick!!! Although it works fine - it is plastic - and can / will break off if you are not careful! With that in mind, you simply need to enter in an appropriate code for your key, and select the style of key you want to print. You may want to have a nail file on hand, to remove any extra bits of plastic first. Leave the code number blank, to generate a random key. I would love to see copies that anyone prints - however - BEWARE - you might not want to post a working copy of your house key - someone else might print one too!
If you hold the key in your left hand, with the blade pointing to the right, the KeyCutCode reads from left to right. 0 for no cut up to 9 for a maximum cut. (0 to 6 when using the Kwikset defaults)  You can switch to the 'top' view in 'customizer', and hold your key in front of the screen while you adjust the values. It may take a couple of prints to find just the right match, fortunately it doesn't take long to print, and doesn't use up a whole lot of your filament. You might want to print your first try using the 'straight' key header, to save even more time / filament!
To get the key to slide in nice and easy, use a nail file to buff / round off the tip of the key. Make sure it feels nice and smooth when you run your finger along the front.  It also helps if you buff / smooth  the front and back sides just a bit.  For the house key, it helps if you buff the upper half of  the back side just a little as well.
For the safe key, I had to do some buffing around the outside of the cylinder pin slots, but with just a little work, I can now reproduce a working key for my home safe - Kind of scary!   I bet that the latest printer will work straight from the build platform.

author: _MF

description.text:
This assembly will accommodate filament spools ranging from 20-52mm diameter, and 12cm deep. Hopefully will cover the majority of spools out there. It's been tested with Hatchbox 1kg ABS/PLA, Hatchbox 1lb, Taulman 618 & 645 1lb, Ninjaflex 1/2 kg. The spool rides on two hubs fitted with ball bearings, feeding into the filament guide, feeding into the stock filament guide, and finally into the extruder. (pictures to come) You will need to print: Da Vinci Hub x 2 Da Vinci Spool Carrier x 1 Da Vinci Filament Guides x 1 Da Vinci Quick Release Spool Fastener x1 or Da Vinci Threaded Spool Fastener If printing for the 2.0, you'll need another set of the above. I used this initially, but it was very time consuming to change spools so I modified the quick release I found elsewhere.
Hub spools require 608 bearing
I plasti-dipped the inward hub face to increase traction on the spools. Probably isn't needed however.
Quick release uses a 3mm bolt & nut.
You'll notice each of the hangers has a cut slot to fit into the Davinci case spline to prevent movement.
I printed all hangers at 90% infill. At least the spool hangers should be for necessary strength for the long rod (thats what she said)
The threaded rod prints the proper size on 50% infill or less, but 90% infill it prints too large - too large for the bearings to fit. I needed to sand the rod down post-print.
Finally the filament guide twin towers need to be offset rearwards so the rear canopy can fit.
With this installation the rear canopy can only open maybe 20cms.
Good enough for changing filaments.

comments.text: Built this and found that the holes in the cones are under sized so I had to drill them out as I have no CAD package to fix it.   Also the spool holders hit the cover as noted by TheCure.  Printed the cones in red and the rest in white.

description.text: I've found it useful in terms of modularity, to be able to insert a capture nut in the place where a 608 ball bearing might be. This thing is a very simple cylinder with a capture nut indent. Otherwise, there is a thru hole the allow 5/16" rod to pass all the way through. It mates nicely with this thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5679 Depending on your printer, it could be a very tight fit. I heat the receiver with a heat gun, and then press fit the captured nut bearing into the receiving hole.

1) Look at your various objects that use bearings and determine if any piece can be reused by having a captured nut instead.
2) Print a few of these
3) Press fit a nut into the hexagonal recess of this thing. Works best as a press fit if you heat the thing and then press the nut into place (permanent connection)
4) Press fit the thing, which now has the captured nut, into the place that is the size of a 608 bearing.
5) Rejoice!

title: LED module
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted something that I could put in different vases that I printed out for people where they could have everything needed to turn on and off the light as well and an easy way to change the battery.  
All in one LED, battery, switch, module for homemade tea lights.  Only one extra wire required and some krazy glue/epoxy for sticking the two parts together.

Print out the module.stl which contains two parts for assembly (have printed it in PLA, 25% infil with 2 perimeters).
SCAD file is attached to make changes at your liesure. Parts used in my version:
CR2032 battery holder: http://shop.evilmadscientist.com/productsmenu/partsmenu/537
Switch: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/9609
10mm RGB LED (cycling, slow): https://www.sparkfun.com/products/11452 I had these laying around from different projects but it looks like this coin cell holder could work as well (with some SCAD tweaking):
https://www.sparkfun.com/products/8822 Used one segment of ethernet wire to connect the negative terminal to the switch, everything else was direct from LED lead to switch/battery terminal, no glue or epoxy was used to hold the switch in, it snapped in pretty easily.

comments.text: Very nice, I'm working on a solderless style tea light that also acts as a switch. Glad to see someone else is making tea lights.

title: Rad Reindeer - Multi Purpose Fridge Tool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Rad Reindeer The Rad Reindeer multi purpose refrigerator tool, solves a great variety of problems inside your fridge.
Having problems with bottles, cans rolling around your fridge? 
Just stack up multiple Rad Reindeer's together to create a chain to rack up your bottles.
Having problems with dripping wine or beverage bottles ? 
Just tilt the Rad Reindeer on its "antlers" to lift the tip of your bottle from the ground.
Having problems with open food bags ? 
Just use the two implemented clips on the "Rad Reindeer's " head to seal the bags.
On top of that it loves the cold, because as a cute Reindeer it can withstand temperatures below zero without a fuss.
The Rad Reindeer looks slick in every Fridge and is a must have item to get.
